Dear Mr. Bell:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 1/10/2022-
1/21/2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
MISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that
violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant

Except as otherwise provided in this subsection and

ADM 980 ADOPTION CLOSING SUMMARY (DHS-222)
A copy of the closing summary must be sent within 14
calendar days of the adoption finalization date to the foster
care worker and the Department of Health and Services
(DHHS) adoption monitor for purchase of service cases for

SRM 200 Personnel Training
Security Awareness Training is required to be taken within
six months of working in a position with CW-CHRI access
and every two years thereafter. CPAs are responsible for
ensuring all personnel with CHRI access completes SAT
timely. SAT certificates must be maintained in all employee
personnel files and/or their LMS transcripts to confirm
completion of training
20 of 27 staff required to complete the training were out of compliance at the time of

FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan
(ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan due
date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three business
days prior to a planned change of placement or no later
than three business days after an unplanned placement
change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case
closure date or one business day after unplanned court
ordered dismissal.
7

Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM. The
DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business days
of the FTM.
8 of 14 applicable open foster care case files reviewed were missing required FTMs
and/or were missing the required forms for FTMs recorded to have been held.

FOM 722-08A ONGOING CASE SERVICE PLANS - AGENCY SIGNATURES
Prior to finalizing, the caseworker and supervisor must
review the case service plan and all linked assessments
and treatment plans during a face-to-face meeting. Case
service plan review may occur during monthly case
consultation (supervision).
The supervisor must review and approve the service plan
within 14 calendar days of the report date.

were not approved by the supervisor within the required 14 days.

FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Caseworker
 Supervisor
 Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are
placed apart
 Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
 Youth ages 14 and older.
8

 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court-ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must check
yes or no for the following when signing the treatment
plan:
 I have participated in the development of the Case
Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
 I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
 I have been provided a copy of the Case Service
Plan and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to review,
and I will have the opportunity to express my
disagreement with the Case Service Plan and Parent

presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign

document actions needed to secure the parent’s and/or

FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes in
a case, including: • Child fatality. • Change in caseworker or
organization. • Change in parent contact information. • Foster
care transfer to adoption. • Change in placement. • Temporary
break from placement. • Program or case closing.
COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS The caseworker must
complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary and upload to MiSACWIS within the timeframe
required for the specified action/change.
9

Placement Change - Prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement change.
Foster Care/ Juvenile Justice Program/Case Closure -
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure.
Caseworker/ Organization Change - Within three business
days of change in caseworker and/or organization.

FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport. Per MCL 722.954c.
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child/youth's placement date to the following
 Foster care provider.
 Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward.
- Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
- At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are
not required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
- At or prior to each placement.
- Quarterly.
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's
medical passport to another caseworker must sign and
date the medical passport verifying that s/he has sought
10

and obtained the necessary information under law and
Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
(MDHHS) policy.
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties
is documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and
dated signature page into the Health Profile section.
6 of 14 applicable open case files reviewed did not contain all medical passports
completed as required
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection report dated 12/30/2019, CAP Approved 1/24/2020
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 SRM 103 requires official transcripts for staff and supervisor of DHHS contracted
programs rather than copies
 Foster home reports documenting water hazards on-site, should not only
document alarms on doors, but also reach pole/rescue ring/etc.
 Adoptive family recommendation deferrals should only be made for issues
outside of agency control, such as fingerprint results, special evals, extenuating
circumstances regarding paperwork collection. The need to collect the basic
required paperwork and/or complete interviews should not be a reason for a
deferred recommendation.
 There must be a consistent method for uploading documents into case records
for which placement is not defined in policy.
 All applicable elements of quality visit standards must be documented.
 Supervisors must ensure that all requested edits are made to reports before
approving and signing them.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
During the course of the inspection, it was discovered that there was confusion
about the files for which DCWL provides regulation. It was discussed that DCWL
only reviews files of youth who are being served by the CPA license, CB390267474
for the purpose of this review. This includes all DHHS contracted cases and non-
contracted cases (foster care and adoption) served by a DCWL licensed programs.
Programs that operate solely under federal contracts or other DCWL licenses (CCI
or other licensed/contracted offices) are not to be included in the review of this
11

license. If a program holds multiple contracts, only the requirements of the DHHS
contract will be reviewed by DCWL.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
I reviewed all aspects of this investigation and determined that it was completed
thoroughly and accurately.
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first approved CAP was in response to SIR 2021C0212002 in which the agency
was cited for violating rule 400.12303(2)(M) for not following agency policy regarding
a youth’s personal possessions. The agency has maintained compliance with the
CAP which was approved on 12/21/2021.
The second approved CAP was in response to the licensing renewal inspection
report. The agency has not maintained compliance with that CAP as evidenced by
the number of repeat violations discovered during this inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator assessment identified several areas of non-compliance
confirmed during this inspection. Those areas were attributed to low staffing, high
turnover rates, and pandemic related restrictions. I identified several additional areas
of non-compliance which were not identified in the assessment which I discussed with
the chief administrator.
Interviews
All of the staff interviewed reported being satisfied with the level of supervision and
support they receive. Despite low staffing and rapid staff turnover, the workers all
report maintaining manageable caseloads.
VII. DCWL ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety concerns were identified.
12

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
